answer_html: And we see there that the function is decreasing on the interval (\(-\infty\),0) and increasing on the intervals (0,3) and (3,\(+\infty\)).
answer_latex:
And we see there that the function is decreasing on the interval
($-\infty$,0) and increasing on the intervals (0,3) and (3,$+\infty$).
hints_html: This was partially if not completely solved two problems ago. Use the derivative and make a sign chart.
hints_latex:
This was partially if not completely solved two problems ago. Use the
derivative and make a sign chart.
hints_raw: This was partially if not completely solved two problems ago. Use the derivative and make a sign chart.
question: 4 (iv)
sols_html:
In part ii) of this question we obtained the sign table of the derivative:

[c]@llllll@ & & \(\displaystyle 0\) & & \(\displaystyle 3\) &
\(\displaystyle x\) & \(\displaystyle -\) & \(\displaystyle 0\) & \(\displaystyle +\) & & \(\displaystyle +\)
 \(\displaystyle (x-3)^2\) & \(\displaystyle +\) & & \(\displaystyle +\) & \(\displaystyle 0\) & \(\displaystyle +\)
 \(\displaystyle f'(x)\) & \(\displaystyle -\) & \(\displaystyle 0\) & \(\displaystyle +\) & \(\displaystyle 0\) & \(\displaystyle +\)
 \(\displaystyle f(x)\) & \(\displaystyle \searrow\) & & \(\displaystyle \nearrow\) & & \(\displaystyle \nearrow\)

And we see there that the function is decreasing on the interval (\(-\infty\),0) and increasing on the intervals (0,3) and (3,\(+\infty\)).
sols_latex:
In
{part
\emph{ii)} of this question} we obtained the sign table of the
derivative:

\begin{longtable}[c]{@{}llllll@{}}
& & $\displaystyle 0$ & & $\displaystyle 3$ &\\
$\displaystyle x$ & $\displaystyle -$ & $\displaystyle 0$ &
$\displaystyle +$ & & $\displaystyle +$\\
~$\displaystyle (x-3)^2$ & $\displaystyle +$ & & $\displaystyle +$ &
$\displaystyle 0$ & $\displaystyle +$\\
~$\displaystyle f'(x)$ & $\displaystyle -$ & $\displaystyle 0$ &
$\displaystyle +$ & $\displaystyle 0$ & $\displaystyle +$\\
~$\displaystyle f(x)$ & $\displaystyle \searrow$ & &
$\displaystyle \nearrow$ & & $\displaystyle \nearrow$\\\\
\end{longtable}

And we see there that the function is decreasing on the interval
($-\infty$,0) and increasing on the intervals (0,3) and (3,$+\infty$).

statement_html:
Consider the function

\[\begin{aligned} f(x) = \frac{1}{4}x^{4} - 2x^{3} + \frac{9}{2}x^{2}.\end{aligned}\]

iv) Determine the interval(s) for which f(x) is increasing and decreasing, respectively.
statement_latex:
Consider the function

\begin{align*}
f(x) = \frac{1}{4}x^{4} - 2x^{3} + \frac{9}{2}x^{2}.
\end{align*} iv) Determine
the interval(s) for which f(x) is increasing and decreasing,
respectively.
statement_raw:
Consider the function
:<math>
f(x) = \frac{1}{4}x^{4} - 2x^{3} + \frac{9}{2}x^{2}.
</math>
iv) Determine the interval(s) for which f(x) is increasing and decreasing, respectively.
